awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel for 2019 USENIX Research Conferences: File and Storage Technologies 2019, Networked Systems Design and Implementation 2019, USENIX Annual Technical Conference 20
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Association presents conferences at the forefront of computing innovation and research that build collaborations between researchers and practitioners from industry, government, and academia. These events provide educational, mentorship, and networking opportunities of very high value to graduate students in the computer sciences who attend. To help increase the representation and participation of these students, this proposal provides funding to assist approximately 20-25 US-based graduate students to attend each of the following events:

17th USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST 2019)
16th USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI 2019) 
2019 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (ATC 2019)

The knowledge shared and advanced at these conferences has practical and meaningful application to many tools used in daily life, as well as to the ethical, cultural, and social ramifications of computing technology. This grant allows the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference, and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. USENIX is an open access organization, and all research and results presented and published at these events are freely available to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Through this grant, the NSF provided USENIX travel funding to assist US-based graduate students to attend three USENIX events in 2019, specifically the Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST '19), the Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI '19) and the Annual Technical Conference (ATC '19). Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field, and exposes students to leading edge work in the field. This grant made possible the participation of graduate level students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences, and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. Participating students at each event were offered specific activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including the student meetup, game night, birds-of-a-feather sessions, and the poster sessions/receptions.

The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for NSDI '19, FAST '19, and ATC '19.  Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants have two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. For those students selected, USENIX covered registration costs by providing students with a registration code for full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided a check to assist the student with costs related to airfare and hotel. Variations in the flat rates offered depend on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested (i.e., some students may stay with a friend in the town of the conference and therefore did not have a hotel expense). We confirmed that the students registered and attended the event. 

The criteria we looked at in selecting grant recipients included:

 ●      Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster)

●      Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics

●      Concision of supporting statement outlining the applicant's research

●      Application history, prioritizing first time applicants and applicants who had not received a grant in the previous 12 months

●      Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events

●      Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities

●      Class level and financial need

 

The NSF funds supported a total of 65 grants for students to participate in the three events. Grants provided across the events are detailed below: 

  • For NSDI '19, USENIX received 63 grant applications from students and awarded 34 grants. The NSF funds of $17,950 covered 20 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 313 total attendees, which included 131 student attendees. 

  • For FAST '19, USENIX received 63 grant applications from students and awarded 28 grants. The NSF funds of $22,200 covered 20 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 327 total attendees, which included 86 student attendees in total. 

  • For ATC '19 USENIX received 56 grant applications from students and awarded 31 grants. The NSF funds of $24,405 covered 25 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 446 total attendees, of which 111 were students. 






 

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2022
Modified by: Camille Mulligan

Image
  • Some of our awardees of the FAST 2019 student grants.
    @usenix
    Camille Mulligan
    FAST '19 Grantees
